Have you ever seen an elephant? Elephants are big. They have grey or brown "skin," large ears and a long nose. An elephantâ€™s nose is called a trunk.
Elephants live together in big groups called herds. Baby elephants are called calves.
Even elephant calves are big. They weigh about 120 kilograms when they are born! Elephant calves learn from their parents.
An elephant uses its trunk like an arm or hand. A trunk can bend and stretch to help the elephant.
Elephants use their trunks to eat food. They pick up leaves with their trunks and put them in their mouths.
Elephants bathe in lakes or rivers. They use their trunks to spray water on themselves and other elephants.
After they "bathe," elephants throw dirt on their backs. The dirt protects elephants from the strong sun.
Elephant skin is tough and wrinkly. This is a very close picture of an elephant's skin.
Many elephants also have tusks. Tusks are really big teeth! Elephants use their tusks to dig.
